finding.description: Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 9090 may expose CiscoSecure/WebSM services to attackers.
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses or on all ports may expose resources to attackers.
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 3389 or UDP port 3389 may expose RDP services to attackers.

This bucket is public and can be accessed by anyone on the Internet. "allUsers" represents anyone on the Internet, and "allAuthenticatedUsers" represents anyone who is authenticated with a Google account; neither is constrained to users within your organization.
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 9090 may expose CiscoSecure/WebSM services to attackers.

To reduce the attack surface, avoid assigning public IP addresses to your VMs. Stopped instances may still be flagged with a Public IP finding, e.g. if the network interfaces are configured to assign an ephemeral public IP on start. Ensure the network configurations for stopped instances do not include external access.

To avoid leaking sensitive data in transit through unencrypted communications, all incoming connections to your SQL database instance should use SSL. Learn more at: https:cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql/configure-ssl-instance

A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26642) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
hostPath volumes mount files or directories from the host. These volumes present security risks that could lead to container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26923) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
Pods that share host namespaces allow Pod processes to communicate with host processes and gather host information, which could lead to a container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26643) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
hostPath volumes mount files or directories from the host. These volumes present security risks that could lead to container escape.

You can explicitly allow a container to run as the root user if the runAsUser or the USER directive in the image specifies the root user. The lack of preventive security controls when running as the root user increases the risk of container escape.
Pods that share host namespaces allow Pod processes to communicate with host processes and gather host information, which could lead to a container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26925) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

You can explicitly allow a container to run as the root user if the runAsUser or the USER directive in the image specifies the root user. The lack of preventive security controls when running as the root user increases the risk of container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26921) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26924) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

A container can be explicitly configured to allow privilege escalation on execution. This permits a process created within the container by executing a set-user-id, set-group-id, or file capability executable to gain the privileges specified by the executable. The lack of preventive security control increases the risk of container escape.

A container can be explicitly configured to allow privilege escalation on execution. This permits a process created within the container by executing a set-user-id, set-group-id, or file capability executable to gain the privileges specified by the executable. The lack of preventive security control increases the risk of container escape.
